bestBHT.bht: It is better for him that a millstone were hanged about his neck and he were cast into the sea. The struggle between light and darkness will inevitably cause stumblings, but not less guilty is he who willfully makes any to stumble. Whosoever shall do the least injury to the meanest person that believes in Christ shall undergo the severest punishment. Christ is not speaking of little children in age, but of such as belong to him; his disciples and followers.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: For whosoever shall offend one of these little ones that believe in me... it is better for him that a millstone were hanged about his neck and he were cast into the sea."
Here follows a striking verse in :-, 'Woe unto the world because of offences!'... 'For it must needs be that offences come; but woe to that man by whom the offence cometh!'"
The struggle between light and darkness will inevitably cause stumblings, but not less guilty is he who willfully makes any to stumble.
Marvin Vincent: Millstone. Rev., great millstone. See on Matthew 18:6. Wyc., millstone of asses. Note the graphic present and perfect tenses; the millstone is hanged, and he hath been cast.
Philip Schaff: The connection is probably with Mark 9:37, as there represented, but the question of John and the answer to it prepared for this advance of thought.
By their conduct in that case they had been in danger of giving such offence.
The actual child was probably still in His arms.
John Gill: Whosoever shall do the least injury to the meanest person that believes in Christ...shall undergo the severest punishment.
Christ is not speaking of little children in age...but of such as belong to him; his disciples and followers.
It is better for him that a millstone were hanged about his neck, and he were cast into the sea; and drowned there.
John Wesley: On the contrary, whosoever shall offend the very least Christian. Matthew 18:6; Luke 17:1.

bhtAttempts.bht: It is better for him that a millstone were hanged about his neck and he were cast into the sea. The struggle between light and darkness will inevitably cause stumblings, but not less guilty is he who willfully makes any to stumble. Whosoever shall do the least injury to the meanest person that believes in Christ shall undergo the severest punishment. Christ is not speaking of little children in age, but of such as belong to him; his disciples and followers.

It is better for him that a millstone were hanged about his neck and he were cast into the sea. The struggle between light and darkness will inevitably cause stumblings, but not less guilty is he who willfully makes any to stumble. Whosoever shall do the least injury to the meanest person that believes in Christ shall undergo the severest punishment. Christ is not speaking of little children in age, but of such as belong to him; his disciples and followers.

Whoever offends one of these little ones who believe in me, it is better for him that a millstone were hanged about his neck and he were cast into the sea. The struggle between light and darkness will inevitably cause stumblings, but not less guilty is he who willfully makes any to stumble. Whosoever shall do the least injury to the meanest person that believes in Christ shall undergo the severest punishment. Christ is not speaking of little children in age, but of such as belong to him; his disciples and followers.

Whoever offends one of these little ones who believe in me, it is better for him that a millstone were hanged about his neck and he were cast into the sea. The struggle between light and darkness will inevitably cause stumblings, but not less guilty is he who willfully makes any to stumble. Whosoever shall do the least injury to the meanest person that believes in Christ shall undergo the severest punishment. Christ is not speaking of little children in age, but of such as belong to him; his disciples and followers.

Whoever offends one of these little ones who believe in me will face severe consequences. It is better for him that a millstone were hanged about his neck and he were cast into the sea. The struggle between light and darkness will inevitably cause stumblings, but not less guilty is he who willfully makes any to stumble. Those who harm even the least person that believes in Christ shall undergo the severest punishment. Christ is referring to his disciples and followers, not solely to little children in age.
